review: Works well but ONLY streams (to Samsung HDTV) what is seen "live" by (MacBook Pro) laptop in a Google Chrome browser window.  E.g., if laptop is tuned to show a YouTube using Chrome, that's what TV shows.  So far I have found no way to show anything brought up in another bowser, nor without browser at all (such as a DVD playing in the DVD slot).  If you're subscribed to a service playable in Chrome, then that will appear on your HDTV. In essence, the device mirrors merely what Chrome shows, period.The setup is much more complicated than the ads and box suggest: A download is needed, and other steps are involved which are tactically not mentioned until they are required.  But it all worked, as far as setup goes.
author: L. Jagerman

review: I own this, two Roku boxes and a WDTV Live.This is a great concept, but, as of right now, it doesn't do much. It's about a third the price of a Roku, but it does probably less than a third of what a Roku does. Only really supports Netflix and YouTube. Yes, you can send anything that Chrome plays to your TV, but the quality of that image is nothing you want to watch for any kind of extended period.When it supports more stuff (hulu plus, HBO GO), it will be a better option, but for now, get a Roku and resist the price tag. You get what you pay for.Update (1/2/14) - Okay, so now the thing is great. Casting a tab running a video still isn't great, but now that Hulu and HBO Go work with it, it's pretty cool. I honestly feel like Google set the price too low when you compare it to Apple TV or a Roku box, but I am okay with paying less.
